ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a deeper understanding of investment management in theory and practice, with a particular focus on endowment management. I learned about different asset classes (domestic equity, absolute return, venture capital, etc.), various investment strategies, the alignment of interests between limited partners and general partners, ethical investing, the tradeoff between passive and active management, and asset allocation. Skills-wise, I learned how to write short memos that discussed investment topics or evaluated managers.
I gained a better understanding of the tenets of value investing and the temperament it takes to be a steward of capital.
More understanding on picking managers, the endowment's and family offices' business models, importance of ethics and integrity in business.
I learned so much about the qualities of asset managers, Yale model, and how to write investment memos.

I learned (from the best!) about different asset classes, how to best structure, manage, and run a university endowment, how to structure a portfolio based on the institution/firm, and how to think about different investment ideas.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The professors were kind, generous with their time, great at teaching, and obviously very knowledgeable about the subject matter. David (rest and peace) and Dean revolutionized the endowment management industry, and it was an honor and pleasure to learn from them every Monday. The curriculum was comprehensive; we got to learn about a wide variety of asset classes, investment strategies, and investment topics. The guest speakers in the class were outstanding in every way. I can't think of many weaknesses. If I had to give one, I'd say that we didn't get much guidance on the assignments (5 two-page memos), though I don't think they were supposed to be a major focus of the course. And in any case, the teaching assistant, Ilana, made it clear that she would be more than happy to help us, provide feedback, or answer questions if we ever reached out.
I loved the guest speakers and only wish we could have been there in person!

Key strengths: very interesting series of speakers, the chance to learn from the best in the field instructors.

Key weaknesses: perhaps, the course wasn't as demanding at times, leading to lesser engagement.
I think the class could benefit from being more interactive by asking students questions about readings and allowing room for more collaboration.

Strengths: very organized weekly lectures (the lecture/conversation was natural yet structured and flowed well), incredible guest speakers that were truly passionate about what they do and very open to sharing their experience and giving advice to students, assignments that were close to what analysts do working in an endowments, opportunity to interact with two professors who run the world's best performing university endowment!!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course ran as smoothly as it could've, given the fact that everything was online. This class was a seminar, so for most sessions the professors didn't need to share their screens or use slides. Technological difficulties rarely got in the way. We just had discussions. The only real difficulty was coordinating and splitting up work with group members for our two presentations, though I think that was more on us (the students) and less on the professors. And once someone got the ball rolling by setting up a group chat or initial email, things worked out just fine!
Mandatory attendance and video-on.

I'm very touched by the dedication from speakers, Professor David Swensen, and Dean Takahaski. Professor Swensen's commitment to foster an extraordinary learning experience for us is evidenced in every class, even until the last week before he passed away.

Starting off each guest speaker class with a fun fact and introducing ourselves helped the class feel less like a typical zoom class and helped the conversations feel more natural (similarly to how students and professors would sometimes chat before and after a class in person).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Of course. I'm not exactly sure how the course will change now that Professor Swensen has passed away, but I am confident that future iterations of the course will still have much to offer students. Professor Takahashi is wonderful and knows so much about endowment management, having helped revolutionize the field. You'll learn a ton from his insights and experiences. You'll get an inside peek at how the Yale endowment functions. You'll learn about a wide variety of asset classes and investment strategies and how to think like an institutional investor. Hopefully, you'll also get the chance to hear from some fabulous guest speakers from the investing world, like we did.
Yes, definitely a fantastic course to learn about investing from storied professionals.
Yes, if not for anything else, for meeting and hearing from the top investors around the globe.
If you get into this class, you have to take it. It is a lot of work - yet I repeat you have to take it. You will learn so much information from your professors and peers that YOU HAVE TO TAKE IT!!!!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was maybe one session that was like a lecture, but the rest of the sessions were conducted as seminars. All classes were held on Zoom.
I truly appreciate being able to learn about asset allocation, manager selection, and markets from the best investors.
Virtual seminar.
